In this episode of The Smart City
Podcast I had a great conversation with a fellow member of the Smart
Cities Council Emerging Innovators Group
Janine Betz. I'll start by saying that everything
we discussed is personal opinion only and does not represent the companies
we work for and is not associated in any way with these companies. Now with that out of the way, Janine is a passionate advocate for sustainability and using Smart techniques to help fight against climate
change. Western Australia is really lucky to
benefit from Janine's background as she
brings the European approach to sustainability and molds it to suit the Australian
conditions and environment. We discussed about the challenges and opportunities building a six
star Green Star Rating project and how Smart Cities is about the
integration between sustainability and innovation. Janine also talks passionately about Western Australia finding its feet
in terms of culture, growth and identity, and how Western Australia is well on their way to leading certain aspects of Smart Cities. As always I really hope you enjoy listening to this episode as much as I enjoyed making it. [The Smart City Podcast Intro
Music.] Well let's jump straight into this and in order to introduce yourself, can you tell us a little bit about
your background? Yes, sure. So you'll probably notice very quickly that I have a bit of an
accent and I am indeed not from Australia. I was born and raised in Germany and have been here since 2007. I have an engineering background with a Major in Architecture and Urban Design, and a Post-Grad. Certificate in Sustainability and Climate Policy. I currently work for the LendLease communities business in the WA. Yeah, wow, cool. So Janine and I are part of the Smart Cities Council Emerging Innovators Group. That's how we kind
of got to know each other. So what sparked your interest in Smart Cities? Well I think that the conversation about Smart Cities is possibly one of the most important ones occurring at this point in time. As we know climate change and sustainability as a whole is a challenge of our time. And I'm just very keen to be part of that. And I guess coming to Australia as an outsider, I have a bit of, kind of two perspectives. You know one that is very much shaped by the European approach, which is very much around different countries working together and that in combination with the Australian perspective
where we're quite isolated geographically, I think that's something that's
always on my mind as to how I sort of balance the two mindsets. And that has I guess prompted me to be involved and just share some of the insights that I get through being in touch with my home country, which is Germany, whilst also
working in Australia. Cool. Are there any particular technologies or concepts that you've come across that you're really interested or are
already exploring? Yeah so for me it's really-- Smart Cities really involves around the human experience. To me people are the central aspects of how we design our city. Obviously I'm going to say that, I'm an architect so you know how can we use technology
to make the experience of our urban fabric richer. And obviously in the beginning Building Information Modelling has been around in Europe for quite some time. I wrote my thesis on that in 2006 and there was already a trend in Europe and has since become a trend in Australia. So that, you know, I guess at the building level is something that
I'm really interested in, and how can we
utilize that technology (BIM) to really have a Smart system whereby we know everything about our
buildings beyond the construction itself but also technologies that allow us to map and model human behaviour and then facilitate a participatory design approach to really ensure that we speak to the right people at the right time and get positive outcomes. So really to me technology is a way of getting to a point where we design cities in a way that they improve the experience that the citizen has. Yeah cool yeah. I'm really interested in BIM as well-- so Building Information
Modelling-- from a horizontal perspective because I think vertical buildings and that kind of thing, it's quite advanced. Whereas I see so much potential for roads and bridges and our horizontal infrastructure to know where the services are, so you know your water pipes and all that kind of stuff, that real integrated approach not just with the buildings but all this other infrastructure
that we have running under our feet or under our wheels of our cars and that kind of thing. Yeah I 100% agree. It's really a holistic approach that looks at the whole city as it relates to buildings individually. But how do they relate to each other, how do they interact and how do you link that to the infrastructure? You know, the horizontal element
that you've mentioned. So that's something, I think it's quite exciting. There's a lot of really cool stuff already happening in Europe and certainly you know big land development projects in the Middle East as well. Where you can then add the human element into it and really allow technology to sort of assist the process of design from the beginning but also at the refinement stage, when sometimes projects don't work as well as they were intended to or people invent new ways of using the spaces that you create. So I think if we get to that point where we have that participation from a user perspective and feed that data back into the models that we create, we have a real-- a lifecycle really of data that starts at design
inception construction to the maintenance and the usage of our cities. Yeah, definitely. So let's talk about right now. What are some of the projects and things you're working on? So through the work that I'm doing with Lend Lease I'm involved with a very exciting project called Alkimos Beach. It is the first project in Australia to receive these six star rating from the Green Building Council of Australia, and as part of that we obviously have a whole lot of commitments that we've made and that certification and the commitments that come with that really inform every single decision that we make along the way. So it's a very interesting project that will run for a few more years and we have just launched a new project also here in WA called Alkimos Vista. Both projects are very close to the
coast so indeed as we're speaking now I'm actually looking out to the
ocean, because our beautiful sales office
is in a really good spot. I guess greenfield development really needs to be at the forefront in many ways of considering Smart because I feel we've got a responsibility to be as Smart as we can in terms of future-proofing the communities that we create. And it is something that we are
thinking about not only here in WA but LendLease as a business more broadly, not only in property but across the different businesses and areas that we are operating in. But speaking about communities there are obviously
strategies in place that are specifically aimed at creating Smart communities and things like fibre to the home etc. are already in place in most communities including Alkimos Beach. So that's the project that I am most intimately involved with. But I also manage the innovation framework for
LendLease property in WA and as part of that global group of project leads and guides across the world really, I get snippets of what LendLease is working on through their innovation arm. It's quite interesting. While sorry I can't share too many
details but it is quite good to get that insight. Yeah, definitely. I know you will obviously be restricted. I totally understand with the amount of details, but the project that you mentioned, is some key aspects you can tell us about that really set it apart from other projects to get that six start rating? Well there's many different aspects to it. And they range, obviously it's an environmental rating. Well at least that's how many people
understand it. However it actually goes far
beyond the environmental aspect of it, it goes on to the community aspect, to the economic aspect. So our commitments and therefore our initiatives on the ground they range from something like a solar battery storage, which we have on site at the moment. It's a trial in Australia which is unique and we are conducting that in collaboration with various government agencies or service providers here in WA. That's one of the highlights of the project. So we mandate solar hot water systems and solar PV systems on every single
home. That's one thing. The other one is of course the use of recycled materials onsite. We have a recycling program in place, which the builders can utilise on site so that diverts landfill. Up to 90% of construction waste is diverted from landfill. You know the list goes on and on. I could talk for a very long
time. But we have got a designated sustainability manager who manages our commitment that we have in terms of maintaining that credit. And she is sort of the interface between us and the GBCA. But it's very much something as a project team, if you have a rating or certification like like a 6-star Green Star Rating, it's not something that you can just achieve and then you drop it. It's an ongoing commitment and it requires buy in from everybody at any point
in time because it is sometimes a bit restrictive in the decisions
that you can make whilst you're developing a projects. Because you've made that commitment
so you obviously need to make sure that there's no breach of that. So as a result you need people who are committed, who are driven and understand the
importance of it because what we've found is
that often people don't necessarily understand what it actually means to try to develop a carbon neutral green field development. So there is a lot of education that still needs to take place as well. But getting back to Smart components, the fact that we have got fibre to every single home here at Alkimos
Beach and really good connectivity and Wi-Fi coverage, then of course enables us to rollout technologies that we may be working on to make the city or the area more Smart Yeah, cool. Can you give us an example of some
of the Smart tech you're thinking about implementing, or some of the Smart tech, even if it's not in this projuct, some of the Smart tech that you
think is interesting that should be implemented? Yeah well that I guess will very quickly go on for me to share a challenge I guess with you. For example Smart bins is something that we see elsewhere in the world already implemented and we sometimes run into problems with local governments to actually see the value in Smart bins in their parks. Because every park that we develop in a project will then eventually be handed over to the respective council. Now if they don't see value in those assets they may not want those assets in their parks basically. So whilst this is just to give you that example of
Smart bins, that's something that we really want
to drive. And we know that in other areas in Australia this is less of a problem. But certainly here in WA we're still having to-- With this
particular council there's still a bit of consultation that needs to occur. And then of course you talk about Smart poles. So the ability to install light poles that not only are Smart in their energy
efficiency, like LEDs, but also record traffic data, they might record the wind direction which is important to inform the sand drift management strategy and things like that. So yes there is quite a bit of technology already available and we're certainly watching that space very closely to
see what we can implement. Yeah definitely. Let's focus on Western Australia. Do you think that Western Australia
ranks fairly high when it comes to Smart
Cities or certain aspects of Smart Cities? Well certain aspects yes. I mean there are areas in WA that are extremely progressive and I'm maybe biased because I
happen to live in Fremantle but the city of Fremantle is
actually quite progressive. They also have a One Planet Living certification and of course the very famous White Gum Valley Project, which trials a whole range of
different innovative things with the CRC for low carbon living and those examples really provide a bit of hope I guess in that there is a recognition of the need for action among
government. I would say however that in Australia generally we're probably ranking maybe mid level when it comes to our commitment to driving Smart cities. Certainly when you compare it to, say Europe, where the EU as a body really drives it through initiatives like the Climate-KIC, the Europe Innovation Partnership, I think it's called EIP. And they have long accepted that climate change exists and they have prioritised I guess actions to mitigate the risk of climate change. And that I think has yet to happen to that degree in Australia. Yeah definitely. So you see the Smart City space as kind of an integration between sustainability and innovation, would that be about right? Yeah I think that's a really good
point. And I think that-- I mean, innovation and Smart and sustainability have sort of gone
through that cycle of being buzzwords. And there's a lot of greenwash and there will be a lot of-- I don't
know, what would be the equivalent term for what green wash would be for Smart. Maybe Smartwash? But I think that you've got to be really really
careful as well as how to use those terms. But what I also think it's you know innovation. In Australia quite often we get
really excited about things that we consider innovative and yes they're quite innovative for
Australia. But if we apply a broader lens and look to other countries then a lot of what we consider innovative is BAU in other countries where sustainability and innovation is already part of
the culture. So we are such a Smart country in Australia, really you know benefiting from so many different backgrounds culturally and and I guess a professional point of view. I really think that there's
potential for us to be a leader of Smart Cities once we we have a shift of mindset and concentrate our efforts and decide where we want to go as a country. Yeah definitely. So do you think that Western
Australia is a good place to pilot Smart tech and Smart concepts? You know are they quite progressive policy and regulation? Well I think that we do benefit from a number of young leaders or emerging leaders. I don't know what is the right term in the government in Australia. So we have obviously had a change of government recently, although I can't vote, not being a citizen. But there is certainly great opportunity for change and we are already seeing that. So I think, to answer your question, yes there is great opportunity here. I really think that WA in particular, those who haven't been here
recently, has experienced a very significant growth in terms of its maturity and certainly in the short time that I've been here-- just over 10
years-- the city has really changed very significantly, found its feet, embraced its identity. And not only from an urban development point of view, have great things happen, but that's been a bit of a shift of
mindset, I feel, for people to actually embrace the fact that yes we're far away
from everybody else and yes everyone thinks you've got
to wait awhile for things to happen in Australia and sometimes they do. But there is a bit of, there's quite a good energy here at this point in time. So yeah I'm quite confident that we'll make our mark. Yeah, cool. So do you think that we can better integrate across
the disciplines. You know, as in government, universities, industries or do you think they're
doing it quite well in WA? Well there's possibly always room for improvement, I think, just generally speaking there's few areas in the world who do get that 100 percent right. And the key is just to keep an open dialogue. And I find that certainly industry organizations like the EDIA and the PCA, Institute of Architects, Planners etc. I don't know over east (Australia), but certainly
in W.A. are quite a strong voice and it's a very closely, well-connected community, with quite a bit of overlap between the different industry organisations and their members. And I think the foundation is really very, very good in W.A. What I do feel and again, that opinion is informed by my German background, is that there's more opportunity for industry and academia to come together and then inform policies at a government level and really have the voice of the younger emerging generation heard, especially the students and foster that sense of collaboration very early on. Because you really need from day one as you enter and you know academic institutions really need to foster that
collaboration between the facilities that they embody. So you know, have Engineering talk
to the Architecture Faculty and to the Computer Engineering, Mechanical etc. so that there is a holistic approach to the education. But then also make sure that
students get exposure to industry from day one, so they don't leave as graduates who are a little bit perhaps surprised by the realities of Smart cities or the development industry more broadly. Yes, so kind of giving them exposure to that early on so then when they come out they're, for want of a better term, more useful to an employer straight away and have a grasp of reality rather than just a purely academic kind of approach to things. That's right. And just to expand on that, it works the other way around as well. If industry was a bit less concerned about IP and I know that this is perhaps a
very naive comment on my behalf, but if we could actually engage with academic institutions through research that would really be wonderful I believe. You get the student involved with your projects that you're
working on and you can share that widely and it's great for the student but it's also great for that industry organisation or that company because they get the, I guess, IP from from the students and they can work on on problems or challenges that they are facing in that moment. But it's just say a resource that is not used very widely if at all. Yeah I agree. I've seen a little bit of it
emerging lately with this technology. Particularly in for example self-driving cars or connected vehicle technology. Using PHD or even you know Masters students or whatever, to kind of build
projects that then industry can-- You know, they get a very economical resource, for want of a better word, a free resource to kind of really dive deep into something that they're really
interested in and then at the end they come out with a product which then they can sell to the government or other industries. So yeah I definitely think we'll see more of that and I think it's a
really good way of thinking about things
because it's kind of a win-win -win for industry, government and academia. So I think, I would really like to see more of
that and I think through the Smart City approach we will see more of that. Yeah because ultimately the word Smart implies that you are strategic in your approach, whatever it may
relate to. So, to not make use of that resource is not very Smart. But yeah I mean I think there are certain government
agencies that do it quite well. And one reason why I love the White Gum Valley
Project so much is that it actually, you know-- Yes, it's fairly small in scale but high impact because it involves
so many different parties. Including obviously Curtin
University who has made available a number of really great researches and a number of PHD students and that information, like you say, will flow back to the government agency that are
developing the project. Yeah. I know you mentioned before about
Western Australia/Australia being leaders in some areas of Smart City. Do you think that we can kind of, or we already are leaders in some
areas? I mean there's always areas of
improvement obviously, but can you, with your background from Europe, can you see Australia where we're the peaks and troughs of Smart city and whether we can improve those areas or learn from others or teach others. What are your thoughts about that? Think I asked you 4 questions in
one, just then. Yeah look I think that Australia is well placed for a number of different reasons. One being that we don't have the legacy that is the urban fabric like Europe has. And by that I mean we are not
constrained by too much heritage in terms of our buildings and the boundaries of our cities. So I think that whilst this can be a blessing and a curse, in this context, perhaps it is a bit of a blessing in that we can find new ways and different ways that would not ever work in Europe. And one example is that the sheer scale of how we grow as a country and development obviously follows that. And whilst I work in
greenfield development, I would at any point promote infield development and urban regeneration over greenfield development. Because that's a more sustainable way of
developing. But when we do develop at a large scale you know entire new communities for 15- 20- 30 thousand people. That scale you know, that's just in my native country, we wouldn't see that. So you know there's a really good opportunity to do things right and work with the technologies as they are available. And Australians are so ready to embrace technology and gadgets. And I think that as a collective we're really, once we acknowledge that we can be change makers through our engagement with technology. And once we have more people on board I really think
we're really well-placed to lead in some aspects of Smart Cities Movement. Whether it's energy or transport. But I really think that the fact that people so readily and happily use technology in this country is a real bonus for us in implementing strategies that rely on technology being used by the wider population. Yeah cool no. It's a really good point. I suppose, I think in some aspects it may be that heritage, I mean we obviously have some
heritage but not to the scale of the buildings and the boundaries of Europe. So it's a really interesting way to think about. I suppose that's the
architect in you. But how we can reinvigorate urban areas as a more sustainable way of developing, that's really
interesting. I agree. Cool. So there is a lot of talk about emerging trends. You know, a lot of buzzwords around. What do you think the emerging
trends are that people aren't talking about at
the moment. Well, I think one of the things that people talk too much
about are electric vehicles, with all due respect to electric vehicles, but they won't solve the issues that we have relating to congestion and health and poor planning. So yeah I would like to see a much, much broader discussion about
transport and I know this is already
happening. But I would like for that conversation to really focus on a holistic approach as opposed to the one element, namely the electric vehicles as well. There is a lot of opportunity to reduce the extent of road infrastructure through integrated transit and gaining more green space and public open space
for the benefit of the public. So I would like to really have that at the forefront of the
conversation, after all, not about technology itself but it's about making sure that the cities become more livable and that we can
accelerate sustainable sustainability efforts. And we also need to ensure that whatever cities we plan we do that in a way that is
inclusive and it's not only accessible to those who embrace technology. So by that I mean if we end up with cities that are great for the tech nerds who will walk around with their iPhone all the time, and are glued to the
screen and have got 50 odd different apps on their phone. That's-- We run the risk of losing people who are not like that. So we've got to be very very mindful and also disciplined to not exaggerate in how much technology we implement into our cities. What I would like to see is for that technology to be largely invisible, to just works in the underground or somewhere where it's not as obvious. And I think if there's an opportunity to customize the experience that the person has with the environment, that where we really great. To give you an example, in Amsterdam which is probably one of the most amazing places in terms of Smart Cities. For those who are maybe listening if
you haven't heard of it then look it up, they have a very, very good Web site. It's called Amsterdam Smart City. It's a great platform which is open to everybody, residents, industry, government. It's a public-private partnership to really drive Smart initiatives and it's a really good reminder of what you really want to get to. That's, to me, that is like a model. If we get that level of
participation at all levels of society that would be really wonderful. But one of the things that they've developed is an app that lets cyclists, and you know there are very many
cyclists in the Netherlands in general, but also in Amsterdam, and it lets cyclists switch on street lights along their bike path as they're
driving or as they're cycling past through
their phone. So you know something like that, I think is pretty cool. And obviously it has the benefit of not wasting more energy than it's needed for one city who runs the asset that is a street light. But for the user it also gives a really great experience. You know I'm a cyclist myself and if I could do that when I'm riding along after dark it would be great. Yeah definitely. That sort of thing, if we could have a bit more of that, it'd be awesome. Yeah, definitely. That's really cool. Well it's been great to talk to you
this afternoon. Definitely lots of things going
through my mind now thinking about merging architecture and engineering and the center of it all being people. So yes. My last question is how can people connect with you. LinkedIn is probably the best way to find me. My name is Janine Betz. I think there's only one. And just send me a message and hopefully you hear this podcast and maybe you want to comment on it and then hopefully Zoe you will share those comments with me. Yeah definitely. Yeah sure will. I'll put all the links in the show notes anyway. People should be able to connect with you that way. Cool, so great to talk to you this
afternoon and we'll definitely talk again
soon. Thanks very much for having me, Zoe. No worries Have a great day. You too. Bye Bye. Thanks so much for listening to the
Smart City Podcast Show notes for this episode and all other episodes can be found at thesmartcitypodcast.com If you have any questions or comments from me or any of my guests, connect with me via e-mail:
zoe@thesmartcitypodcast.com or via the socials. I'm on Twitter and Facebook
@SmartCityPod. As always I hope you enjoyed
listening to this episode as much as I've
enjoyed making it.

Guten Tag, Herr Spahn,  vielen vielen Dank, dass Sie sich Zeit für uns genommen haben. - Schönen guten Tag. Hallo! - Ja. Sie haben heute gesagt, "die Ruhe vor dem Sturm" haben wir gerade. Das wäre tatsächlich meine Einstiegsfrage. Also wieso sollte der Sturm erst jetzt kommen,  weil gefühlt um uns herum, in den ganzen Ländern da ist es ja schon ziemliche Sturmstimmung. Also was erwartet uns noch  und warum ist es bei uns gerade noch die Ruhe vor dem Sturm? - Wir haben eine besondere Situation, die übrigens viele andere Länder auch fragen lässt,  was ist eigentlich los bei euch in Deutschland? Wir haben eine realtiv hohe Zahl von erkannten Infektionen um die 40.000 und eine vergleichsweise geringere Zahl von auch Todesfällen zu beklagen. Und das zeigt uns, dass wir, weil wir sehr viele Tests machen,  wir hatten letzte Woche fast 300.000 Corona-Tests in Deutschland. Das ist mehr als jedes andere Land auf der Welt. Dass wir also sehr frühzeitig die Entwicklungen erkannt haben und erkennen und deswegen wahrscheinlich noch relativ weit links in der Kurve der Entwicklung sind. Weil wir sehen auch in anderen Ländern, wie schnell es dann gehen kann, wenn sich die Zahlen zu schnell, mit zu wenig Abstand verdoppeln. Und dann ja vor allem auch die Zahl der Schwerstbehandlungsbedürftigten steigt. Toi, toi, toi! Im Moment sind relativ viele Intensivkapazitäten in Deutschland noch frei. Wir haben ja Maßnahmen ergriffen,  damit die Betten auch leer werden, von planbaren Operationen. Im Moment warten sozusagen alle noch auf das, was passieren kann und das meinte ich mit dieser Aussage "Ruhe vor dem Sturm". - Das heißt, es könnte auch sein, dass dieser Sturm so gar nicht kommt? Also dass wir mehr oder weniger glimpflich durch diese Situation kommen? - Das kann zum jetzigen Zeitpunkt niemand sagen. Was ich sagen kann, ist, dass wir ja selbst den Schlüssel in der Hand haben, jeder der jetzt auch zuschaut, dazu, wie sehr der Sturm stürmisch wird sozusagen.  Es geht ja darum, Kontakte zu reduzieren, um die Verbreitung des Virus' zu verlangsamen. Das ist ja für jeden von uns ein ziemlicher Einschnitt im Alltag. Kontakt zu Freunden, zur Familie, zu Partnern, manchmal zu den Enkelkindern, zu Großeltern zu reduzieren, Um eben dem Virus möglichst schwer zu machen, sich zu verbreiten. Ich werde versuchen vielleicht auch meine Dankbarkeit,  mehr mit einem Lächeln zu zeigen. Vielen, vielen Dank - ich lächele jetzt an Sie, dass Sie sich die Zeit genommen haben, weil ich weiß, Sie haben momentan sehr viel zu tun. Ich finde das toll, wie Sie sich einsetzen für unser Land und ich glaube da sind ganz viele Menschen draußen, die Ihnen dafür sehr dankbar sind. Vielen, vielen Dank und ich wünsche Ihnen ganz viel Erfolg und ich hoffe, dass wir das einfach zusammen schnell schaffen. - Das wünsche ich mir auch! Dankeschön und Grüße an alle.

Untertitel:

den Nächsten infiziert, aber nicht einer zwei Nächste

war und am 23. März war das Datum, als in den meisten Bundesländern

über die Schulschließungen. Und am 16. März, am Montag,

der Verlauf eines ganzen Monats. Und man sieht,

in ganz Deutschland. Das ist nachvollziehbar. Ich kann mich dran erinnern,
wie das damals war. Das war eine Zeit, in der in Berlin

gegangen bin. Da war kein Auto mehr auf

Macht man die Schulen zu? Andere Länder
hatten das schon gemacht. Das war ein bestehender Eindruck,
der auch eine Wirkung hatte. Es stimmt nicht,
dass ab dem 23. erst bestimmte Veränderungen
in Kraft traten in der Bevölkerung. Das war deutlich vorher. Dann muss man sich vergegenwärtigen: Dieses stufenweise Einführen von
Maßnahmen führte auch stufenweise zu einer Verringerung
der Übertragungstätigkeit. Man kann das nachzeichnen

neuen Fällen kann man das sehen, die vom Robert Koch-Institut

ging aber immer noch weiter. Das ist nach einer gewissen Zeit

der Schutzmaßnahmen. Man sieht einen Abfall Anfang April,

ist, auch mit der Neuinzidenz. Und das ist, dass sich in dieser

und in Krankenhäusern. Also in Sondersituationen,
wo man eine Situation hat fast wie ein Haushalt,
aber viel größer. Dort konnten diese Kontaktmaßnahmen
nicht greifen. Es gibt viertens
noch einen anderen Effekt, der noch nicht so stark erfasst ist

um einen erheblichen Faktor. Ich habe mir
die Daten rausgeschrieben. Es wurden 87.000 Tests gemacht in

dann sieht es manchmal so aus: Als wäre die Grundtätigkeit
wieder nach unten verändert. Das ist etwas, das ich im Moment

stiegen und die Diagnostik stieg und dann aber

wuchs nicht mehr weiter an. Ich bin mir sicher,
ich habe ein starkes Gefühl, dass das auch eine Verzerrung der

kam nicht mehr so viel dazu, wie die Statistik erwartete,

die Modelle rechnet, so etwas mit einzubeziehen. Ich bin gespannt,
was dabei rauskommt. Wir haben mehrere Effekte,
die man dagegenhalten kann. Gegen diese Mutmaßung, dass
der Lockdown nichts gebracht hat. Ich denke, das ist

wenn wir diese drei Punkte nehmen, an den Maßnahmen verhängt wurden. Es gab es Faktoren zwischendurch, dass Menschen Empfehlungen
zum Abstandhalten eingehalten haben. Richtig. Und man muss sich vor Augen führen,

R im Bereich von 0,2 kann man erreichen

um da schon drauf zu gucken. Da Sie das Stichwort

Phase eins, Studien am Menschen in China
laufen schon. Und warum wurde
die Entscheidung getroffen? Das sieht man

than the factor of two you see here in the

how did that happen? What is it? Is it cancer drugs? What kind of science did it? And the answer is
although some of it is just nutrition and income
levels, the general advance of GDP per person and the
living conditions you're under. By far, most of
that is vaccines. Measles vaccine alone is over
a million of that reduction. Smallpox vaccine
that led actually to the first
eradication of a disease altogether is a huge
part of this reduction. Well over a million
death reduction per year because of that. And so vaccines,
which get less than 1% of the focus on medical
spending, goes into that area. They are responsible for
a really incredible amount of health benefit. Even in rich countries it's
a underappreciated element of why things work. And they're very cheap. The manufacturing
cost comes down over time to most a few
dollars you can deliver them. As a group, you don't need
trained medical personnel to do it. And even in a country like
Somalia, where you essentially, have no government, we have
quite high vaccination rates. Actually much better than
we have in northern Nigeria, northern India, where you have
a dysfunctional vaccination system that's only getting to
30% in some of those areas. So it's a huge problem we have
to fix, while at the same time, we add in these new vaccines. When you think about the
inequities of the child to death-- I always think about how
is the way you can state that that is the most clear? One that I think is
interesting is to say, other people who are born
the same year you were, your birth cohort, how old were
you before 20% of you had died? And in a rich country
in the United States, you'd get past age 60
before 20% had died. In a poor country,
the poorest, you wouldn't get past age
four before 20% had died. So you had a very
dramatic difference. The thing that was mind blowing
when I found out about this is the effect that
improved health has on population growth. The first thing
our foundation did actually was invest in
reproductive health, because we said, okay,
whatever the problems you're interested in, not having too
many more people, whether it's jobs, education, food,
environment, to not have sort of Malthusian growth levels
like 3%, 4%, 5% a year, which we fortunately, only
have in a few places now, that is a primary problem. And I wasn't sure how to think
about health interventions, because are you schizophrenic? Do you want more
people or less people, and wouldn't that be
the first class effect? Well, the answer is no. Paradoxically, the
biggest intervention that reduces the family size
that people want to have is improving Childhood Health. There's some others like
female literacy and things that can be done. Hans Rosling, who's
from Karolinska, has a presentation on the web. A Ted presentation, a number
of others, where he really articulates there's only
two kinds of countries, there's high population growth
countries with terrible health, and there's low population
growth countries with reasonable
health, and there's no in between because
this effect is so powerful that as you
improve Childhood Health, parents who are trying to have a
few kids survive into adulthood choose not to have as
large a family size. So what you get is as soon as
you start to improve health, all these other things
become tractable, and you have many countries
that we used to think of as poor and received aid-- even South
Korea 30 years ago got aid-- now, it's quite a
generous aid donor. So it's a complete
turnaround from recipient to giving within
a 40-year period, but it's true of China,
Brazil, lots of countries. So now we're down to
what Paul Collier calls the bottom billion, maybe
a billion and a half or so that are in this poverty
trap that we still need to better on. And the good news is that
despite the complexities and difficulties
of these things, something like vaccinations
can be delivered anywhere. So inventing those,
getting them to be cheap, getting them out, getting a
slightly better distribution system will allow us to go from
that slightly under 9 million that we're at today, down to
5 million down to 2.5 million, and it has this
huge, huge effect. The other problem I want to
take as an illustrative example is education. And education economists
of all the things that's known for sure,
investing in education, primary, secondary,
college level, doing that in quality
way is the thing that really allows a country to
improve its standard of living. So both that at macro level, but
also at the individual level. We all know from our
personal experience that education is what makes
our life interesting, gives us opportunity, and
so we should want it to be broadly available. If you look-- and I was
absolutely blown away at the statistics, I had no
idea of how poorly the education system in the US is working. Over 30% of kids drop
out of high school. If you're a minority, over
50% drop out of high school. Even the ones who
complete, many of them have had a really,
really poor education. And so they sign up
for college, they get into a remedial math
class, and half of those kids never get any degree. So they've got loans
they're paying off, they've got this
negative experience, they put time into it, and it
hasn't worked for them at all. And so this education
system is quite poor, and it's been covered up,
hasn't been that visible. What we have now is a trend
that because of the way state budgets are allocated,
a great education is going to be more and more
out of reach, that is, the tuition is more expensive. And so we literally will have a
situation where less people are getting college
educations unless we do something fairly dramatic
to improve the efficiency. Make some type of breakthrough. So I'd say there's two things
that are very important. One is to take the
quality of teaching, and this is particularly
in K through 12, and find out what the
best practices are, and how to spread
those best practices. And it blows my
mind how little work has been done on
that to identify, now that we know some teachers
are wildly better than most teachers, you make over two
years of progress in math if you get a top
quartile teacher, and you make zero
years of progress if you get a bottom
quartile teacher. So what's going on? Is it seniority? We know it's not. Is it having a PhD in math? Actually, we know
it's not that either. That has a very
little affect on it, although people
are focused on it. There's huge differences of how
the kids are being drawn in, and yet we don't study that. We don't invest in
spreading it around. We don't measure teachers,
give them feedback, it's a system, where there's
a huge opportunity to improve, so that's important. And the other thing I
think is using technology. And here's a case where
MIT has absolutely been at the forefront. OpenCourseWare,
there's great numbers in terms of how much it's being
used by millions of people. I'm a super happy user. I retook physics
with Walter Lewin, I took Professor Sataway's
course and loved that. I recommended it to everybody. Eric Lander, biology, refresher
on differential equations, actually of the 33 that they
have videos, I've taken 11. And I just last night
spotted two new ones that I need to take, so just
for me, it's a good thing. But this is just the beginning. And MIT did spark a lot of
people to do similar things, but the percentage of
people using these things and the difficulty
of finding something and testing their knowledge. Really bringing the best of
video, the best professors in the world, have
interactive experiments, interactive ways of testing your
knowledge, even accreditation. Have a way that if you have
gathered this knowledge instead of that all coming
bundled with a degree where you had to be somewhere
for four years, fairly expensive, say, quarter million. Actually have the
accreditation piece be separated out, so
you can have innovation, in terms of how people
acquire the knowledge, and separate it from
place based learning. Now the exact path
to this is not clear. There's some schools
like Rocketship, who even at the middle school
level, are using online courses and mixing that in
with live teaching. It's an area that
needs to be tried, and you have to keep
the kids motivated, you have to help when they
get confused, some of that will be face-to-face, but
there's online innovation there too. Right now, it's all
pretty fragmented. Different universities
doing different courses. It's kind of hard
to find things. Academic growth has a
little bit of an aggregation there, but that this can
improve very substantially. I was talking with Victor
Xu about how we take speech recognition and bring that in. We were talking about making it
more modular if you just want to learn different concepts. So we are just scratching
the surface, and the need to take this and
have teachers be able to learn how to teach
better, to assign kids who are ahead, to assign
kids who are behind, or to have self-motivated
people going and use this and have it be
a worldwide resource that's very clear who should
use what, that's something that needs get done. And again, it's what's
been done so far has had very modest funding. This is an area we need more
resources, more bright minds, and certainly one that I want
to see how the foundation can make a contribution to this. So if you look at the
two issues, childhood deaths, education, or if
you look at the other ones. Savings, where the cell phone
can bring down the transaction costs, sanitation or advanced
physics and chemistry you really can do that
in a different way. Energy may be the
toughest one of all, but again, one where MIT is
marshalling its resources to make a strong
contribution as it can. These important
problems, there's reasons to believe we
can't make progress, but that rate of progress will
be somewhat proportional to how we draw people in. Draw them in full
time, draw them in part time on these issues. So it does leave this,
almost meta question of how to get the
brightest people more on to these big problems. Why don't they work on them? Well, the economic rewards
aren't totally in line with these problems. That's interesting, we can think
about what would change that. The visibility, getting
the success stories out, how can we do that? My dream is that, say a few
years from now, I'll go off and I'll have a weekend,
and instead of talking about March Madness
and stock prices, we'll have these brackets
about the best teaching and which ideas have been
tried, team teaching, online, and we'll be comparing
which has really come out with the best outcomes. And then we'll talk
about food and the best seeds, the new agricultural
practices that are increasing this productivity, and we'll
have that same excitement and understanding that we
have about other topics. I don't think that specifically
is going to be easy to achieve, but it's kind of
the high bar of why aren't these topics as
interesting, as engaging as those other things. And if we really
did that, yes, we might delay the invention
of a new financial product by a few years, we might even
delayed that baldness drugs by a few years. But if it helps on the
important problems, I think it's a good thing. Thank you. [APPLAUSE] Great. Well, the rest of

like to be told, you can't have more than
a certain number of kids, but at the same time,

it to 18 to 16 to 14, and now the consensus

to be 8.5 or something, the problem is that population

have coercive techniques, and they just didn't understand. So you have a very
positive view of this. People want to have

rate, it'll get to 90 million because they have the

is that the rich countries are shrinking. The US is the only rich country

don't have good vaccination. And so in a way, it's
good news because you do the interventions with
the reproductive health and the vaccines and
the childhood care all in the same places,
and it's very focused where you go and do that work. BRYAN: My name's Alan Bryan. I am in the Health
Sciences and Technology. I have a PhD in Bioinformatics. I'm a medical student,

it harder, and this is based on your past experience

education reform, is it harder to figure out
what best practices really are that are

or some teacher's personal patterns of
action or something. Or is it harder to talk through

we are science limited. That is, an AIDS

it is interesting, but it's taking us a lot longer
because we haven't gotten lucky on that one. So that is science limited. Malaria vaccine it's
criminal that we didn't work on it, because probably
the science of the 80s or 90s were good enough to
do a malaria vaccine. They were not good enough
to know an AIDS vaccine. Even if we'd been
working super hard, we just don't have the
fundamental understanding. Most of the diseases we work on,
the vaccines aren't that hard, it's just there wasn't
money put into it, and so now it's moving
at full speed now. And the delivery
thing, we're going to have to raise
money, billions, but you're talking about saving
lives for less than $2,000 invested that is funding
vaccination it saves lives for less than $2,000. And because in the US we'll
spend $2 million or $20 million to save a life,
then you say, okay, are these lives really less
than 1,000 times as valuable? I mean, maybe there
are 400 as valuable, but 1,000, that's
getting kind of extreme. I mean, even in
the Constitution, slaves were worth what? 3/5 of the vote or
something like that. So in terms of
discrimination, numerically, this is pretty extreme stuff if
you fail to fund the vaccines, which right now, in
the budget crisis, we're having challenges with
that, but in the long run, we won't. On cold chain, there's
this great science of these super thermoses
that should avoid us having to use electrification, which
is very tough because if it goes out, the vaccines spoils,
and electricity policies in these countries are so bad
that using a solution that's passive energy to get the
cold basically ice in a super or in a Dewar's
type thing, we think we can replace cold chain. But even if we have to use
refrigerators, we can do it. You have to over buy the
vaccines because of the fact that some of the
most will spoil. So that one is science limited. The education one, even
though we don't know-- it's mind blowing
how little we know about what good
teachers do and how you would invest in
spreading that around, I think that will finally get
some good work going on. The field needs about 50 times
as many people working on it, we need the schools of education
to show up and get serious about this. We need some of
the methodologies of real measurement
to be applied to it. The hardest thing there,
even once we know what to do, is going to be convincing

school that there's 82 of these schools that

and get over 95% of them to go to college and

of being in there, they have some amazing

practice, which is a I'm doing God's

stuff type system that there are many great

effort to spread that. We have five sites in the US
that we've given $400 million to where the union
and the district signed up to have
teacher measurement. So we put webcams in so
you can see the video, you don't have people

that we were going to try to get a consensus. Four years from now,

hey, I like this. They got rid of

it was not high overhead, and I really like this. If that can happen
in the five sites, and they can tell everybody
else, that would be good. If you say, what's the riskiest
thing the foundation is doing? It's that teacher
personnel's activity because the status quo is
immensely powerful there. When we invent vaccines, no
group, I won't name who it is, can uninvent the vaccine. If you do good
education, there are groups that can send
you back to square zero, and that has happened
in many cases. DENMON: Hello. My name's Matt Denmon, and I'm

researchers, will there be in

a lot of people are looking at radical
battery technology that could, in terms of
cost and capacity, get us in a very

curve will get us to. So you don't want to just bet

and the intermittency thing. Once you get above say, 20%
from intermittent sources, you've got a problem. It's cute, it works
well up to about 20% where you ask the baseload

has the advantage that the amount

molten salt reactors, that's a little bit tricky. The crazy group I'm backing,

fusion guys, they're neutrons are 1,000 times
worse than our neutrons, but even ours or are-- those guys have 14 NPV
neutrons, good luck to them. But some people
should work on that. That is not an easy thing,
in terms of the economics. So nuclear, in terms of
[INAUDIBLE] is incredible, and if you use this approach
we're talking about, it is infinite, that is you
can filter out of the sea very cheaply enough, uranium
to run this thing for as long as the sun will shine. So in that sense, is it
quote, "renewable" quote, well it's infinite. You don't worry about
the amount of uranium. So anyway, I think it's
one of the approaches that a ton more should be done in. We need more money
in material science, we need more money in
batteries, we need more money in transmission, this is
an underinvestment area where if the government
actually does raise trading money
or carbon tax money. Some of the bills that
have been proposed, don't actually fund R&D
at a reasonable level, so it's a tragic
thing that, hopefully, if we get a revenue source, that
we can take the energy, R&D, and get it up maybe a factor
of three or four more. There's a few good things
going on like [INAUDIBLE],, but that doesn't
work for nuclear. But I love I love nuclear. It does this radiation
thing that's tricky, but-- [LAUGHTER] --they're good solutions. It was interesting,
recently in Connecticut, this natural gas
plant blew up 11 guys. Just blew them up, actually,
I think killed 506. If that had been a
nuclear plant everybody would know about that. Coal mines, yeah, China
did a good job last year, they went from 3,300 guys
dying in coal mining accidents, to 2,600. Very impressive,
don't you think? But if nuclear had killed
those 2,600 people, I mean, we would just be-- kiss the whole industry goodbye. It's interesting,
deaths per megawatt, nuclear is the minimizer-- [LAUGHTER] [APPLAUSE] --these things, but it's
got a lot of challenges. But it's great. I'm glad there's this
Renaissance of people going into it. We have this company, and
everybody in the company is either over 60 because
they have done something, or they're in their 20s
or 30s because they're open minded and optimistic. So it's an interesting
bimodal, we don't have anybody
in the 40s and 50s, because that was the
nuclear shut down period is when those people would
have would have been trained. Go ahead. AUDIENCE: Hi. My name is [INAUDIBLE]. I'm a freshman, and I'm
researching with Professor Sataway, actually. And thank you for coming
to MIT, though you probably like Harvard better. GATES: No, no, no. [LAUGHTER] AUDIENCE: Just kidding. So my question is two part. The first part is
that earlier you were talking about how you
think that it'll be a challenge to get a lot of young people
into researching for helping poverty and helping the world
issues because they might not find a financial
incentive in this, and you said that this would
be an interesting drama to look at. But I was wondering,
first of all, if you could elaborate a little
bit on how you would look at this problem and
what sorts of approaches you would take, and do you want
me to say the second part now or after your answer? GATES: Oh, I'll
answer this, then you can do the second part. Part of the solution is to
take corporations, like drug companies, phone
companies, banks, and get them to put
some of their innovators on these problems that are
less renumeration of perhaps, but overall, in terms of
their reputation and hiring and things like that,
and that's happening. We funded a group called
access to medicines that ranks the
pharmaceutical companies, according to how much they
work on diseases of the poor, and it came out like we thought
it would with GSK on top and various other
people in the bottom. And the right thing
happened, which is the people on the bottom
called this up and said, this is embarrassing. Well, are there projects and
things we should be doing? So spreading that to other
end industries, banking, cell phones, the food
companies, been great. We haven't done the index yet,
but the Nestle's, Unilever's, Coke's, their
willingness to work with us on agricultural
sourcing, nutrition products. They've been
amazingly effective. So bringing the
companies in so that you have people working at the
companies who can do the stats is important. Government funding for
these things, which is mostly the delivery piece. That's the foreign
aid budget, making the case for that, that
that should stay strong, it's very important. Getting people
like the NIH, who-- or others, but NIH is big-- to tilt a little bit towards
the disease of the poor in terms of work they do. And Francis Collins,
the current director, is thinking about some creative
things there that'll happen. Ironically, drug
approval is still this weird thing where
poor countries don't trust themselves
to approve drugs, and so when we want
to do a new TV drug, it has to be approved-- no country will accept it
unless either FDA, the US regulator, or EMA, the
European regulator accepts it. And they don't have
the right process for triple drug therapy. They'd make us,
under normal things, go through three
phase 3s, which that's 15 years and over $1 billion. So they're working with
us on these things. We're trying to
get vouchers, where if you do drugs for the
poor, you get faster FDA review on your rich world
drugs, so we need government, philanthropy, and corporate
money to go into this, and that's the economic piece. Then, we need the
visibility, where people feel like this
is a great thing, and there is
progress, whether it's prizes or awards or
things like that, there's a lot more
that can be done. So what's the second one? AUDIENCE: The second
is less academic. I'm just curious, how does being
the richest person in the world affect your life? I mean-- [LAUGHTER] GATES: Well, the marginal
return for extra dollars does drop off. I haven't found any burgers at
any price that are better than McDonald's. [LAUGHTER] [APPLAUSE] There's a few things like
air travel, where it's nice-- [LAUGHTER] But other than that,
overwhelmingly, once you get past,
some point, I don't know what it is, a few
million or something, then it's all about how
you're going to give it back. Are you going to
pick someone, are you going to get
involved yourself, how are you going to do that? And for some people,
strangely, that's actually a burden,
where they're worried they won't to do it well,
or all that, and so partly, making that easier, making
that more widespread is one of the things I think is
interesting that can help more. If we could double philanthropy,
if we could get India and China billionaires, for example, to
be as generous as the US is or get us to be
twice as generous and then get them
to match up to that, it'd be a substantial
amount of money. I guess I've used up all
my time, so thank you. Those were great questions. Let me just leave you with a
small challenge or opportunity, which is that on the
Foundation Facebook website, if you have ideas about
a particular problem or the general issue
of drawing people in, if you have ideas
about that, I encourage you to post there because
I'll go look at that and see if there's things
that we ought to help promote. And hopefully, we'll
get a lot of good ideas. Obviously, coming
here, you are people who believe in these things, so
I want to thank you for that, but think hard about how we can
get even more people involved. [APPLAUSE] SCHANER: So thank
you, Mr. Gates, for taking the time to
answer our questions. Please accept on behalf
of my fellow students, our appreciation for your
interest in our work, and I speak for everyone
here in thanking you for the support and friendship
you've shown to MIT. [APPLAUSE]

Untertitel:
Norddeutscher Rundfunk 2020 Herzlich willkommen zu extra 3. Für viele Deutsche ist Corona
inzwischen wie ein Adventskalender: Welches Türchen
geht als nächstes auf? In vielen Bundeländern hat Ikea
wieder seine Pforten geöffnet. 300 Leute stehen dicht an dicht,
warten auf die Öffnung des Ladens. Beklöppt, wie der Schwede sagt. Auch Frisöre dürfen endlich ihrer
systemrelevanten Arbeit nachgehen. Höchste Zeit. Letzte Woche sahen wir alle aus
wie Pornodarsteller aus den 70ern. Hier ein Bild von mir von Sonntag. Jetzt sehen viele ihren Partner
das erste Mal wieder ohne Matte. "Ach, du bist das? Ich hab mich schon gefragt,
warum ist der Wischmopp so schwer." Gestern verständigten sich
die Ministerpräsidenten mit Kanzlerin Merkel
über das weitere Vorgehen. Die hat konsequenterweise gesagt:
"Macht doch einfach, was ihr wollt." Schließlich haben wir
Föderalismus in Deutschland. Der ist nicht nur dazu da, sich über die PISA-Ergebnisse
der Bundesländer lustig zu machen. Jetzt macht jeder,
wie er es für richtig hält. Es gibt aber
einen Notfallmechanismus: Wenn die Zahlen in einem Landkreis
steigen, dann wird entschieden, wie Lockerungen
zurückgenommen werden. Dann müssen wir zwei Schritte
zurückgehen, und dann wieder vor. Damit hätten wir
den Sommertanz 2020: den Corona. Einen Schritt vor, zwei zurück, zur
Seite, nach vorne, fünf nach hinten, einmal drehen, Cha-Cha-Cha. Viele Ministerpräsidenten hatten
schon Lockerungen bekanntgegeben. Das zeigt doch, wie effizient
unsere Politik derzeit arbeitet. Für Mittwoch eine Konferenz ansetzen und dann die Ergebnisse
schon Tage vorher verkünden. Respekt! Es preschen Länder voran, von
denen man es nicht gedacht hätte. Niedersachen zum Beispiel. SPD-Ministerpräsident Stephan Weil
war eigentlich eher zurückhaltender. Dass er jetzt für sein Land
Lockerungen in Aussicht gestellt hat: Er hat sich nur
über die anderen geärgert. Er hat sich geärgert. "Ich bin so sauer,
jetzt öffne ich auch. Und immer noch einmal mehr als du." In Sachsen-Anhalt sind wieder
Treffen von fünf Menschen erlaubt. Fünf Freunde
treffen sich einfach mal wieder. Das neue Abenteuer. Niedersachsen öffnet
am 11. Mai wieder die Gaststätten, Bayern am 18. Mai die Biergärten. Höre ich mehr?
Dahinten die Dame mit den Locken bietet offene Strände
für alle zu Pfingsten - super! Hier bietet einer offene Kitas. Offene Kitas zum Ersten,
offene zum Zeiten, zum Dritten. Das Höchstgebot kommt
vom kleinen Mann mit der Brille. Armin Laschet will
immer der Lockerste sein. Das ist sein Motto: Er hat auch keine Lust mehr,
auf nervige Virologen zu hören. Die sind sich ja nicht mal
einig in dem, was sie sagen. Heute kommt das, morgen das.
Vielleicht hat er ja Recht. Keiner weiß, ob das stimmt,
das oder ob meine Aussage stimmt. Ich glaube eher, dass das stimmt. Laschet argumentiert auch auf
eine Art streng wissenschaftlich. Er kann es ja selber ausrechnen, wie weit man gehen kann,
wann man wie viel öffnen kann. Das ist alles relativ. Relativ abhängig davon,
wie relativ scharf auf die Kanzlerkandidatur "K"
der Ministerpräsident "MP" ist. Und Laschet ist scharf -
im Quadrat, wie wir sehen. Ob das reicht,
um Kandidat oder Kanzler zu werden: Das ist 'ne andere Frage. Aber ein Lied anstimmen,
kann man doch schon mal. ♪ Ah, oh, Laschet ♪ In Berlin galt Laschet
lange als "Babyelefant", als Mann der zweiten Reihe. In der zweiten Liga. ♪ Oh, Baby, Baby, Elefantenbaby Die in NRW die,
die sind manchmal crazy Er ist ein Gute-Laune-Clown
und er hat einen Traum Er wär gern: ♪ Deutschlands next Mutti. ♪ Dass das klappt, glaub ich kaum Erst ging's ihm bei Corona ... ♪ Um Leben und Tod. ♪ Doch viel schlimmer als der Tod
ist langes Shopping-Verbot Oh, Laschet (Laschet) Er wirkte lasch und blass,

Er macht die Schulen auf ♪ Die Schulen sind nicht vorbereitet. Das ist
in ganz Deutschland gut gelaufen. K-k-k-keine Alleingänge. ♪ Das hat er früher gesagt Doch das sind olle Kamellen,

freut die Mutti gar nicht so sehr ♪ Mich schon. ♪ Und auch die Experten

ins Kanzleramt (Laschet) ♪ Das war ein Song von
Dennis Kaupp und Jesko Friedrich. Nun ein lautes Hurra - endlich
wieder Bundesliga, ruft die "Bild". Darauf hat das Land gewartet.
Leute, wie geil ist das denn? In Stadien,
in die kein Fan reinkommt, spielen Spieler,
die kaum trainiert haben. Für einen Sender, den man
fast nur in Kneipen gucken kann. Die haben aber noch zu. Irre. Nur auf meine Darmspiegelung
habe ich mich je so gefreut. Viele Vereine brauchen die Kohle,
wie der Junkie das Heroin. Um ihr krankes System
am Leben zu erhalten. Ein Verein wie Schalke 04
wäre sonst wohl bald pleite. Nach jedem Spiel suchen die Spieler
den Mittelkreis nach Geld ab, weil sie hoffen,
dass die Seitenwahlmünze da liegt. Zum Glück gibt's in der Liga
ein gutes Sicherheitskonzept. Es wird viel getestet -
und, das hat Seehofer klar gesagt: Bäm! Das ist ein Wort.
So war's ja mal beim 1. FC Köln. Beim 1. FC Köln wurden drei Personen
positiv auf Corona getestet. Sie stehen unter Quarantäne.
Das Training soll aber weitergehen. Nur drei Leute unter Quarantäne? Das Training geht weiter?
Da kannste mal sehen ... Beim Fußball gibt's
eben doch Sonderregeln, der ist systemrelevant -
so wie die Autoindustrie. Das sind die Säulen
unseres Wirtschaftssystems: Karren und Bundeliga,
also Auto- und Menschenhandel. Es gibt aber auch
positive Meldungen vom Fußball. Ein Spieler von Hertha BSC hat revolutionierte nebenbei
dem investigativen Journalismus: Salomon Kalou,
der erste Whistleblower der Welt, der nicht gecheckt hat,
dass er was geblowt hat. Geschweige denn 'ne Whistle. Er hat mit dem Handy live gestreamt,
was er so macht als Hertha-Profi. Er sitzt im fetten Auto,
dann geht er in die Kabine, natürlich gibt er allen die Hand,
wie man's macht in der Corona-Krise. Corona-Virus. Corona-Virus. Und dann filmt er noch
einen Kollegen beim Corona-Test. Der Arzt trägt kaum Schutzkleidung
und reagiert nervös auf das Filmen. Salomon, bitte lösch das.
(Salomon lacht) It's okay. Fine. Die ganze Corona-Sache
ist nämlich total lustig. Und dieses Video kam genau
dann an die Öffentlichkeit, als die Bundesliga zeigen wollte,
wie verantwortungsvoll sie agiert. Kalou wurde suspendiert. Eine Garantie dafür,
das so was nie mehr passiert, denn die anderen
sind ja alle vernünftig. Es heißt ja immer, wegen des Unterhaltungswerts
muss wieder Fußball gespielt werden. Ich muss sagen, wenn die nicht spielen,
sind die noch unterhaltsamer. Auch sonst wird viel geöffnet. Immer mehr Kinder dürfen
in die Kita-Notbetreuung. Anspruch auf Betreuung
haben auch Alleinerziehende. Viele überlegen schon,
ihre Familie zu retten, indem sie sich scheiden lassen. Auch die Schüler
kehren zurück in die Schulen, unter Sicherheitsvorkehrungen. Mit Abstand, Seife und komplizierten
Sicherheitsvorkehrungen der Schulen. Der Unterricht findet
mit offener Tür statt, damit die Schüler
die Türklinken nicht anfassen. Tür offen, Mund geschlossen -
dann kann nichts passieren. Ich empfehle Eltern
von Schulanfängern immer, über Alternativen zu Süßigkeiten
in den Schultüten nachzudenken. Es gibt Mundschutz, Handschuhe
und Helme wegen der Einsturzgefahr. Wir reden von deutschen Schulen. Die geben sich Mühe
im Rahmen ihrer Möglichkeiten. Dem Krisenmanagement der Politik kann man aber
kein gutes Zeugnis ausstellen. Das ist summa cum lausig. Was Kids
für den Schulstart wissen müssen: Jetzt bei "Politik mit Paula". Hallo, Kinder. Ich bin's, Harry, der Hygienehase. Na, ihr Mäuse? Harry hat wohl heute doch keine Zeit,
denn der hat alle Löffel voll zu tun. Der war so überrascht,
dass unsere Politiker die Schulen so schnell
wieder aufmachen wollen. Genauso überrascht wie die Lehrer,
Eltern, Schülersprecher, Hausmeister Schulbusfahrer und jeder,
der kürzlich in einer Schule war. ♪ Humorvolle Musik ♪ Aber dafür könnt ihr
endlich eure Buddys wiedersehen. Ihr dürft sie nicht anfassen. Und die nervigen Nerds
auch nicht verkloppen. Ihr müsst nämlich immer
so weit entfernt voneinander sein. Das könnte in der Klasse
ganz schön tricky werden. Harry und die Politiker verlassen
sich da ganz auf eure Hygienepower. Immer schön die Hände waschen,
mindestens 30 Sekunden. ♪ Zehn kleine Biolehrer
gingen wieder in die Schule Der eine steckte sich mit COVID-19 an
und landete auf der Intensivstation Da waren's nur noch neun ♪ Das macht ihr am besten
nach jeder Schulstunde. Falls ihr ein Waschbecken findet,
das funktioniert. Ich weiß, einige von euch
finden es trotzdem noch scary, wieder zur Schule zu gehen. Aber wisst ihr was? Wenn ihr fest genug daran glaubt,
wird am Ende alles gut. Endlich wieder Schule! Yeah! Jetzt zur wichtigsten aller Fragen: Was machen wir im Sommer?
Werden die Grenzen doch aufgemacht? Oder bleiben die Reiseaussichten
so rosig wie zu DDR-Zeiten? Ins Ausland reisen ist ja
im Moment wie Republikflucht. Wir haben alle gehört,
was Heiko Maas gesagt hat: Niemand wir 2020 einen Urlaub
verbringen können, wie er ihn kennt. An vollen Stränden,
in vollen Berghütten ... Wenn überhaupt,
dann Urlaub in Deutschland. Unter den neuen Bedingungen. An der Nordsee werden schon

Manche empfehlen ja auch den Süden. Vielleicht ein bisschen zu sehr. Man kann auch

wenn man gen Süden fährt, kann man in Bayern sein. Der Norden hat auch

wo man hinfährt. Nord oder Süd,
West ist dann nicht dabei. Westen nicht,

mit Schutzmasken serviert. Bock drauf? Auch in Deutschland
sieht es finster aus. Timmendorfer Strand, das Fichtelgebirge
